newsitem.title: POLAND: Senior banker sees Poland's rating upgrade soon.
newsitem.headline: Senior banker sees Poland's rating upgrade soon.

text.p: Poland should receive a credit rating upgrade within the next few weeks, a senior Polish banker said on Thursday.

Cezary Stypulkowski, president of Bank Handlowy SA, due for privatisation in June, said at a ceremony concluding Handlowy's eurobond placement the bank hoped a higher Polish rating would also improve its own rating.
"We believe that Bank Handlowy is a very strong institution and we believe an upgrade of Poland, which is expected in a few weeks, will be followed by a Handlowy upgrade as well," he said.

But Wieslaw Szczuka, head of the finance ministry's foreign department also at the ceremony, said recent reviews of Poland by Moody's Investors Services and Standard and Poor's did not necessarily mean a rating upgrade would follow.
Analysts have said Poland is ripe for a rating upgrade.
Central Bank Governor Hanna Gronkiewicz-Waltz last month said Poland's improving economic situation justified a higher rating.
Moody's awarded Poland an investment grade Baa3 rating in 1995 and did not change it last year.
Standard and Poor's raised Poland in 1996 to an investment grade BBB minus from a speculative BB given in 1995.
